instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0, No <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and VCORE
threads.message: Hello! This board came here with no power. It had a sticky layer of some undefined substance all over it, like a kind of oil or something. In the beginning the fan was spinning for a few seconds and then die and would do same thing if pressed power button but no fan spin/stop loop if no battery connected and just connected to power. I inspected the whole board under the microscope and could not find anything looking corroded or visually bad, so I decided to ultrasonic clean it because I thought maybe something could be stuck under PCH/CPU making the board not turn on. Now the board is stuck in S0, but no PP1V05 and obviously no VCORE. After some inspection and measurements I found that <RESISTOR>R7614</RESISTOR> was bad, so I replaced it, but same thing. Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0, No <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and VCORE
threads.message:
Missing <SIGNAL>1V05_S0</SIGNAL> implies missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Check traces, solders and components around <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.
Post its voltages; pins 6, 12, 16, 17.
You may need to change it.

Do you get <SIGNAL>1V2_S3</SIGNAL> for sure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0, No <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and VCORE
threads.message:
Yes, <SIGNAL>1V2_S3</SIGNAL> present and stable.

<CHIP>U7600</CHIP>:

Pin 6 - 1.8V
Pin 12 - 5.1V
Pin 16 - 3.3V
Pin 17 - 0V

Already replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, as it seemed a little burned but same result

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0, No <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and VCORE
threads.message: Post diode mode to ground at L7630.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0, No <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and VCORE
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0, No <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and VCORE
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0, No <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and VCORE
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0, No <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and VCORE
threads.message:
You still have a problem at <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> area.
Check all traces, solders and components.
<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> receives power and enable.
